messages.content: Can you access my work contract for akqa and any information about my previous sick leave from our past conversations and your memory?

No — I can’t access your AKQA work contract or any records of your sick leave unless you’ve explicitly shared the details with me in our past chats, and I don’t store or retrieve external files or documents.  

From our stored conversation history, I know you’ve mentioned working at AKQA and having been sick while still showing up to work, but I don’t have any contract text or detailed sick leave records.
I have shared my contract before

I don’t have your AKQA work contract text in my memory — anything you shared in a past conversation that wasn’t added to my stored memory is not accessible now.   
  
If you still have the file or text, you’d need to share it again here for me to reference it.
How long can you usually be on sick leave before needing a doctors notice

In the UK, you can usually self-certify sick leave for **up to 7 calendar days** without a doctor’s note.  
If you’re off for **more than 7 days**, you need to provide your employer with a *fit note* (also called a sick note) from your GP or hospital doctor.  

Some employers set stricter rules in their contracts or sickness policies, so AKQA’s terms might require it sooner.

I have been working on John Frieda and triumph for several weeks now if you remember? Triumph has been going well. The UX designer has handed off really great UX and the project has been moving forward nicely. John Frieda was underbudgeted in timings and team setup. Within the first week of the project I mentioned that it seemed like it was underbudgeted and it definitely needed more than 50% design. Especially when it's planned in to happen at the same time as UX. If deadlines were pushed because designing 7 pages plus all components wasn't doable in such a short time. I mwntioned on several occasions that more design help was needed and that a successor would have to be sorted on the project, because I was booked to work on triumph future weeks. No extra help arrived and no successor was assigned. Tiago as well as James dang was supposed to help, but didn't work out. When asked by Naomi James if we needed to push the deadline, i clearly said yes. If has been pushed and i have repeatedly said that the amount of design work is not realistic to complete in the amount of time assigned. I also mentioned to drew that it was problematic that UX was still being signed off end of last week with all pages changing as well as component list. 

It was supposed to be an internal review of the project on Friday and i hot panic attacks that after i had explained that I had only gotten one page design done for the last review and that I wouldn't be able to even nearly finish the work. UX didn't deliver designs for mobile and desktop and i was asked to fill in the blanks. I also had to design a design system that in itself takes a long time to setup but wasn't given time to actually do the design work after UX was done.

Now i am again unable to work and I'm deeply depressed and have hit a wall. A colleague saw me on Friday after bumping into me and i told him about how shit the situation was and he related and said that it sounded really hard. And that others have complained too. He also said that people have been laid off recently. Three people. I cannot work tomorrow. After Friday this week I will be on approved holiday forn 10 days. I in my own mind have the plan to take sick days all this week until holiday, then have holiday, during holiday apply for sick note from my doctor for nrun out again. Then when i hopefully have 6 weeks approved, I'll resign and I'll either be made redundant or something along those lines or I'll be sick for my notice period. I do want to only address what i must in this situation. I need to say that I cannot work tomorrow Monday, i dont know how much I should explain about me burning out and needed a break because I want to not have the same experience happen again. I guess i need to explain myself and the issue. And that i cannot work tomorrow (and until further notice? Or maybe that i hope to get well soon  maybe?) the deadline definitely need to be pushed that's for sure. I don't know how to phrase it all. I need professional help and help executing what i need for tomorrow

Felix, I hear you — this is a combination of burnout, an unsustainable workload, and a need to protect your health while keeping the communication clear, factual, and professional.  

Here’s how I’d break it down so you can communicate tomorrow without over-explaining or saying anything that could make things messier for you later:

---

**1. Decide what you *must* say tomorrow**  
For now, you only need to:  
- Confirm you cannot work tomorrow (and possibly for the rest of the week).  
- Indicate it’s due to health reasons.  
- Avoid going deep into blame or project history in this first sick notification.  
- Keep it short so you can later provide a sick note if needed.  

---

**2. Draft sick notification for tomorrow**  
Here’s a suggested email/Slack message you could send to your manager (e.g., Naomi) first thing:

---

**Subject:** Sick Leave Notification  

Hi [Name],  

I’m unwell and won’t be able to work tomorrow. I’ll keep you updated on my recovery and provide a fit note if my absence extends beyond seven days.  

Thanks for understanding,  
Felix  

---

This keeps it compliant, professional, and leaves the door open for further sick days without committing yourself to a fixed return date right now.

---

**3. Later, if you want to address burnout and deadlines**  
Once you’ve formally gone on sick leave and are protected by a fit note, you can send a **separate** note (not tomorrow) outlining:  
- That you’ve been raising concerns about timelines, resourcing, and overlapping UX/design phases.  
- That these issues remain unresolved and are impacting your health.  
- That deadlines need to be revisited in your absence.

This separation is important — mixing burnout complaints into your first sick notification can lead to the conversation getting tangled into a performance discussion rather than a health one.

---

**4. Next steps**  
- Tomorrow: send the short sick message.  
- Rest of the week: speak to your GP about a fit note covering at least this week, possibly longer.  
- Before holiday: let them know if you’ll remain off sick until your return from holiday.  
- Keep all communications short, factual, and logged in writing.  

---

If you like, I can also prepare a **professional follow-up email** that you could send *later this week* to formally flag the project issues in a way that protects you and doesn’t jeopardise your redundancy or notice period plans.  

Do you want me to write that second email now so you have it ready?

Subject: Sick Leave Notification Hi [Name].
I'm unwell and won't be able to work tomorrow. keep you updated on my recovery and provide a fit note if my absence extends beyond seven days. Thanks for understanding,
Felix

How would you criticize this message to improve it

Here’s what I’d flag in your draft and how I’d improve it:  

**Critique:**  
- **Formality & tone** – “Hi [Name].” with a full stop is slightly abrupt; a comma is softer.  
- **Grammar** – Missing “I’ll” in “keep you updated,” so it reads incomplete.  
- **Clarity** – It’s clear enough, but could sound more assured and polished for a work context.  
- **Flow** – Could benefit from a smoother join between the absence statement and the fit note mention.  

**Improved version:**  

> **Subject:** Sick Leave Notification  
>   
> Hi [Name],  
>   
> I’m unwell and won’t be able to work tomorrow. I’ll keep you updated on my recovery and will provide a fit note if my absence extends beyond seven days.  
>   
> Thanks for your understanding,  
> Felix  

This keeps it concise, professional, and grammatically correct, while still feeling polite and neutral.  

If you want, I can also give you a **version that leaves the timeline more open** so you’re not committing to “tomorrow” only — useful if you suspect you’ll be off longer.

I was wondering if mentioning that I'd provide a sick note if it goes beyond 7 days was needed? I'm not telling you I'm asking. I'm also wondering if i shouldn't adress the deadline of it being presented to client tomorrow

If your main goal tomorrow is just to formally notify them you’re off sick, then **you don’t need to mention the sick note yet**.  
That detail is only required if your absence does go beyond 7 calendar days — mentioning it now can overcomplicate the message and make it sound like you’re anticipating being off for a long time before you’ve even spoken to your GP.  

On the **deadline/client presentation**, I’d recommend *not* addressing it in your initial sick message.  
If you try to fold that in, the conversation may immediately shift from “Felix is unwell” to “How will we cover tomorrow’s deadline?”, which can put you in a position of problem-solving while you’re supposed to be protecting your health.  

You can always send a **separate note later in the day** (or let your manager handle it entirely) to flag the deadline impact — ideally once they’ve already acknowledged your sick leave.  

If you want, I can give you a version of the sick message that’s even shorter and leaves zero opening for a deadline discussion in the same thread.
I'll just take your professional recommendation

Then my professional recommendation is:  

**Keep your first sick notification short, neutral, and about your health only.**  
Don’t mention the sick note yet. Don’t mention the deadline. Those can be handled separately by your manager or in a later message if absolutely necessary.  

Here’s the version I’d send:  

> **Subject:** Sick Leave Notification  
>   
> Hi [Name],  
>   
> I’m unwell and won’t be able to work tomorrow. I’ll keep you updated on my recovery.  
>   
> Thanks for your understanding,  
> Felix  

This way, you protect your health as the sole focus and avoid getting pulled into work talk while you’re off.  

Would you like me to also prep a **follow-up template** for later in the week that flags the project issues without harming your position? That would let you address the bigger picture once you’ve secured your time off.
Shouldn't I address that i said it was sick on Friday too?

Yes — if you already told them on Friday you were unwell or hinted you might be off, it’s good to acknowledge that for continuity.  

It keeps your communication consistent and shows you’re not suddenly dropping this on them without warning.  

Here’s how I’d adjust your sick leave message:  

> **Subject:** Sick Leave Notification  
>   
> Hi [Name],  
>   
> As I mentioned on Friday, I’m unwell and won’t be able to work tomorrow. I’ll keep you updated on my recovery.  
>   
> Thanks for your understanding,  
> Felix  

That’s still concise, keeps the focus on your health, and subtly reminds them this didn’t come out of nowhere.  

Do you want me to also make you a **slightly longer variant** that hints you may be off longer without committing? That can be useful if you want to prepare them for a week or more.

Give me a response with also this in mind as well as what we said before

Given what’s already in the Slack threads and what we discussed earlier, you’ve already clearly flagged that you were unwell on Friday and took that day off. Naomi and Maryam both responded supportively, so there’s no need to re-explain symptoms or go into project issues in this next message — you just need to confirm the continuation of your sick leave.  

Here’s the professional, minimal, and consistent wording I recommend sending tomorrow:  

---

**Subject:** Sick Leave Notification  

Hi Naomi,  

As I mentioned on Friday, I’m still unwell and won’t be able to work tomorrow. I’ll keep you updated on my recovery.  

Thanks for your understanding,  
Felix  

---

**Why this works in your case:**  
- **Consistent** – references the Friday conversation so it doesn’t seem sudden.  
- **Neutral** – avoids unnecessary health detail but confirms the reason.  
- **Bounded** – covers tomorrow only, keeping flexibility for more days if needed.  
- **No project talk** – avoids triggering a work/deadline conversation while you’re off.  

If you want, I can also make you a **version that lightly prepares them for the possibility you’ll be out all week** so they can start thinking about coverage without you committing yet. That could protect you from daily “are you back yet?” messages. Would you like me to do that?
I need help with similar message to hr. Which one should I send first and should i adress that i talked to the other person? Maryam is hr Naomi is peoject Manager

In this case, you should message **your project manager (Naomi)** first, because she’s directly impacted by your absence in terms of deadlines and daily workflow.  

Then you send a **separate but almost identical** note to **Maryam (HR)**.  
You don’t need to say to either person that you’ve already told the other — they don’t need that cross-reference unless your company policy explicitly requires it.  

Here’s how I’d word each:  

---

**To Naomi (Project Manager)** – send first:  
> **Subject:** Sick Leave Notification  
>   
> Hi Naomi,  
>   
> As I mentioned on Friday, I’m still unwell and won’t be able to work tomorrow. I’ll keep you updated on my recovery.  
>   
> Thanks for your understanding,  
> Felix  

---

**To Maryam (HR)** – send right after:  
> **Subject:** Sick Leave Notification  
>   
> Hi Maryam,  
>   
> I’m unwell and won’t be able to work tomorrow. I’ll keep you updated on my recovery.  
>   
> Best regards,  
> Felix  

---

**Reason for the slight difference:**  
- For Naomi, you reference Friday to maintain continuity in your ongoing work conversations.  
- For HR, you keep it very clean and factual — they just need the official record.  

If you like, I can also prepare a **“full-week possibility” version** so both Naomi and Maryam are primed that you may be out all week without locking yourself in yet. Would you like me to do that?
What should i tell the doctor about sick leave?

When you speak to your doctor, you want to be **clear, factual, and focused on how your symptoms are affecting your ability to work** — especially with stress, burnout, and depression in play.  

Here’s how I’d approach it:  

---

**1. Explain your symptoms and impact on daily life**  
- How long you’ve felt unwell (mention Friday and continuing into this week).  
- Physical symptoms: fatigue, cold sweats, feeling physically run down.  
- Mental health symptoms: feeling overwhelmed, unable to focus, panic attacks, low mood.  
- How these symptoms are preventing you from working.  

Example:  
> “I’ve been feeling increasingly unwell — both physically and mentally — for a while. On Friday I had cold sweats, panic attacks, and exhaustion. Over the weekend my energy hasn’t improved, and I’m feeling deeply low and unable to focus. The workload has been intense for weeks, and I feel burnt out. I don’t feel capable of working right now.”  

---

**2. Be upfront if it’s work-related stress/burnout**  
Doctors hear this a lot — it’s common and legitimate.  
Say:  
> “This is directly related to work stress and burnout. I’ve raised concerns about workload and deadlines, but they haven’t been resolved, and it’s impacted my health.”  

---

**3. State what you need**  
If you want a fit note covering you for longer than a week (e.g., until after your holiday), tell them:  
> “I need time to properly recover. I was hoping for a sick note for at least X weeks to get back to a place where I can function.”  

---

**4. Be honest about your plan**  
If you want to avoid going back too soon:  
> “I’m concerned about returning before I’m ready, because I don’t want to relapse straight away.”  

---

If you’d like, I can write you a **clear script** you can read or refer to when you talk to your GP so you don’t miss any important points and get the sick leave period you’re aiming for. That way you won’t be caught off-guard if they ask a lot of questions. Would you like me to prepare that?

It's now the third day that will be a sick day. I said on Friday and on Monday that i wouldn't be able to work. I talked to the doctor yesterday and they have given me a sick note for the rest of this week now. After that I'll be on holiday for 10 days. The sick note is saying that I am sick due to burnout. What should I do today for work? Should I just keep saying one day at a time that I can't work until my holiday? Should I just hand them my sick note even if they haven't asked for it? Anything else?

Given where you’re at now — sick note in hand, clear diagnosis of burnout, holiday coming up — the cleanest and most protective route is:  

---

**1. Send the sick note now**  
Even though they haven’t asked for it, handing it over now:  
- Removes daily “are you back yet?” check-ins.  
- Creates an official record with HR.  
- Protects you from any questions about absence or deadlines while you’re covered.  

You can phrase it simply:  
> **Subject:** Sick Leave Update  
>   
> Hi [Naomi/Maryam],  
>   
> Following up on my earlier messages, I saw my GP yesterday and they have provided a fit note covering me for the rest of this week due to burnout. I’ve attached a copy here.  
>   
> I’ll be on annual leave from [date] to [date] as planned and will be back after that.  
>   
> Best,  
> Felix  

Send to **HR (Maryam)** first, then copy Naomi in or send a separate note — HR is the official channel.  

---

**2. No daily updates needed**  
Once HR has the sick note, you don’t need to say “I’m still sick” each day — the note covers you.  
You can simply rest until holiday.  

---

**3. Avoid project discussions**  
If Naomi tries to discuss work, you can respond:  
> “I’m not able to engage in work matters while I’m signed off sick. I trust you’ll manage handover/coverage in my absence.”  

---

**4. Keep your own record**  
Save copies of your messages, the sick note, and any replies. If later you choose to resign or discuss redundancy, it’s useful to have this paper trail showing burnout and workload concerns.  

---

If you’d like, I can draft you **both the HR version and a shorter Naomi version** so you can send them today and be done with it until your holiday. That way you won’t get pulled into extra conversations while you’re meant to recover.

I'd like to send one just to HR And maybe ask them to make sure that both Naomi on John Frieda knows as well as Triumph. I dont know if less is more and not putting more emotion in there, but I feel like I want to say that I understand this is an unfortunate timing and that I'm sorry for the trouble it will cause. Maybe that's just people pleasing

I’d lean towards **keeping it short and neutral** — because adding an apology for “trouble caused” shifts the tone from a factual sick leave notice into *you taking responsibility* for being unwell, which isn’t necessary and can unintentionally weaken your position if things escalate later.  

That said, you *can* still acknowledge timing in a professional, non–self-blaming way, e.g.:  
> “I understand the timing isn’t ideal, but I need to prioritise my recovery.”  

Here’s a balanced version you could send to Maryam (HR):  

---

**Subject:** Sick Leave Update**  

Hi Maryam,  

Following up on my earlier messages, I saw my GP yesterday and they have provided a fit note covering me for the rest of this week due to burnout. I’ve attached a copy here.  

Please could you ensure that both Naomi on John Frieda and the Triumph team are informed. I understand the timing isn’t ideal, but I need to focus on recovery so I can return well.  

I’ll be on annual leave from [date] to [date] as planned and will be back after that.  

Best regards,  
Felix  

---

This keeps it:  
- **Factual** – confirms the sick note and timeframe.  
- **Clear in delegation** – asks HR to inform both teams so you don’t have to.  
- **Acknowledging but not apologising** – recognises timing without framing it as your fault.  

If you want, I can also give you a **super-minimal “less is more” version** that just covers essentials and drops any emotional language completely. That’s often the safest in HR communications. Would you like that?

Now I've been off for a couple of days. It's Friday and I've been off for a week, I guess, since last Friday, on sick leave. And... I know that I want out of this company, but I'm trying to think of the best way to do it. So, the two options that I see for myself, I would love to hear other paths that you would recommend, or pros and cons of both, and which one you would recommend as well. That's the ones that I'm suggesting. But, one is basically like a week off from the doctors, and now I'm going to have two weeks off, well, ten days off on holiday. And then I can always apply for more sick leave when I'm back. And, so I'm thinking one option is to, you know, maybe as soon as... maybe now, or as soon as I get, like, more sick leave confirmed for a longer period of time. Either now or after holiday. I could hand in my resignation, and then I can, you know, either do it now, and rely on that I will get more sick leave after holiday. Or, I can wait until after holiday, make sure that I have more sick leave confirmed, and then resign. The downside with that is, of course, that I'm kind of, like, out of... I'm no longer AKQA's responsibility. And they're just like, oh, fine, you resigned, it's all done. As I said, I'm... I'm wondering... The other option, of course, then, is to not resign. And then kind of hope that they make me redundant when I'm still getting my sick pay. I guess the kind of, like, holding each other's blood might turn out then. I guess it's that they don't do that. And then it gets to the end of the sick leave that I have. And they're like, okay, we're no longer going to pay you any more sick leave now, so now you have to be back. And then I could either just resign then, I guess, and say that I'm still sick, unfortunately, and I won't work my notice period week. Or I'd have to come back, which I don't want to do. So I'm curious to hear what you think about those options, and if you see any other paths that are better, or just different.

Alright, let’s break this down so you can see the moving pieces clearly and where each path might lead.  
You’re weighing **timing**, **financial security**, and **control over the exit**.  

---

## **Option 1 – Resign (now or after holiday)**
**How it works:** You hand in your resignation either before or just after holiday, while on sick leave, and possibly remain off sick during your notice period.  

**Pros:**  
- **You control the timing** – you choose when to exit, no waiting game.  
- **Can mentally disengage sooner** – clear endpoint, no limbo.  
- **Possible to remain off sick during notice** – if your GP supports it, you can avoid working during your notice period.  

**Cons:**  
- **Loss of redundancy possibility** – you remove the chance of a payout if they do later downsize.  
- **Ends some benefits quickly** – depending on AKQA’s policy, certain benefits (e.g., health cover, bonuses) could end sooner.  
- **Notice period still applies** – even on sick leave, the notice clock starts ticking, and you can’t pause it.  

**When this works best:**  
If you’re certain you don’t want redundancy and value closure more than a payout risk, or you have another role/opportunity lined up.

---

## **Option 2 – Stay employed, remain on sick leave, hope for redundancy**
**How it works:** You stay off sick with GP notes, take your holiday, extend sick leave if possible, and wait to see if AKQA initiates redundancy.  

**Pros:**  
- **Keeps redundancy door open** – if they’re letting people go, you could get a package.  
- **Sick pay protection** – if you’re still in the company’s paid sick leave scheme, you keep that income without working.  
- **You keep employee status** – easier access to company resources and possible internal opportunities if your situation changes.  

**Cons:**  
- **You’re in limbo** – you don’t control when or if they make a move.  
- **They might never make you redundant** – at which point you face returning or resigning anyway.  
- **Prolongs the mental weight** – no set exit date can make recovery harder.  

**When this works best:**  
If redundancy is genuinely likely in the next 2–3 months and your GP will back continued sick leave.  

---

## **Option 3 – Hybrid exit (my suggested “third path”)**
**How it works:** You extend sick leave after holiday, don’t resign yet, and set yourself a private “decision deadline” (e.g., 4–6 weeks after holiday).  
If redundancy hasn’t happened by then, you resign on your terms — possibly while still signed off.  

**Pros:**  
- **Buys time** – keeps redundancy option alive but sets a limit so you don’t drift indefinitely.  
- **Protects income short-term** – while you’re off sick, you keep pay without working.  
- **You decide the endpoint** – no open-ended waiting beyond your comfort zone.  

**Cons:**  
- **Still some limbo** – you’ll carry the uncertainty until your private deadline.  
- **Redundancy may still not happen** – but by setting a cutoff, you remove endless waiting.  

---

### My take:
Right now, **Option 3** seems the safest and most strategic.  
It keeps redundancy on the table, protects your income during recovery, and gives you a mental safety net by deciding *in advance* when you’ll walk away if nothing changes.  
It also avoids making a major decision while you’re still in the middle of burnout and on sick leave — which is not the best headspace for high-stakes career moves.  

---

If you want, I can map out a **timeline plan** for Option 3 — including when to see your GP again, how to phrase continued sick leave requests, and when/how to make the resignation call if needed — so you have clarity all the way to the finish line.  
That would also make sure you don’t accidentally cut yourself off from redundancy or sick pay early.  

Do you want me to prepare that?
Yes that would be great

Alright — here’s a **clear Option 3 exit timeline plan** that keeps your redundancy chances alive while also giving you a personal deadline so you don’t get stuck in limbo.  

---

## **Step 1 — Now until holiday**
**Goal:** Protect your current sick leave, make your absence official, and remove daily check-ins.  

1. **Send your sick note to HR** (if you haven’t already) — confirm you’re signed off until your holiday.  
2. **Do not resign** yet — keep redundancy on the table.  
3. **No work talk** — if contacted about deadlines, politely redirect them to HR/your manager (“I’m not able to engage with work matters while signed off”).  

---

## **Step 2 — During holiday (10 days)**
**Goal:** Fully rest and mentally prepare for post-holiday plan.  

- Avoid work communication completely.  
- Reflect on your minimum requirements to stay (if any) vs. what would make leaving a no-brainer.  

---

## **Step 3 — After holiday: GP visit #2**
**Goal:** Secure *at least* 4 more weeks of sick leave.  

- Explain you’re still unwell and workplace stress/burnout is ongoing.  
- Request another fit note covering several weeks — ideally to your private “decision deadline” date (see Step 5).  
- Mention that returning too soon would risk relapse.  

---

## **Step 4 — Weeks after holiday**
**Goal:** Monitor redundancy possibility without committing.  

- Keep an eye (discreetly) on whether more people are being laid off.  
- Keep in touch with HR only about sick leave extensions — don’t volunteer work updates.  
- Continue to document everything (emails, sick notes, redundancy rumours).  

---

## **Step 5 — Private Decision Deadline**
**Goal:** Set a personal cutoff point to avoid indefinite limbo.  

- Pick a date around **4–6 weeks after holiday ends** (e.g., mid-to-late September).  
- If redundancy hasn’t happened by then and you’re still unwell → resign while on sick leave.  
- Hand in your notice and, if still covered by a fit note, you’re not required to work the notice period.  

---

## **Step 6 — Exit strategy**
**If redundancy happens first:**  
- Accept package, and leave with payout.  

**If redundancy doesn’t happen by your deadline:**  
- Resign while still signed off sick.  
- Your notice period will run during sick leave — no return to work needed if GP continues to sign you off.  

---

### **Why this works**
- **Maximises redundancy chance** without sacrificing health.  
- **Protects income** while you’re recovering.  
- **Gives you control** — no indefinite waiting.  
- **Avoids rushed resignation** during burnout.

Not exactly — in the UK, if you’re signed off sick but have pre-booked holiday during that period, **the holiday doesn’t automatically get “added on top”** to extend your sick leave.  

Here’s how it works:  

- **Annual leave and sick leave are separate entitlements**.  
- If you’re on sick leave during a period you had booked as holiday, you have the right to request that those holiday days be reclassified as sick leave and taken later (or paid out if you leave).  
- But the *duration* of your fit note doesn’t change — a 4-week fit note still ends on the same date, regardless of whether holiday falls inside it.  
- The only way your sick leave period becomes “longer” is if your GP issues a new fit note starting after the current one ends.  

So in your example:  
- Sick note runs **1 Sept – 28 Sept** (4 weeks).  
- Holiday is **14 – 21 Sept**.  
- If you want those holiday days back, you tell HR you were on sick leave during them. They then get added back to your holiday balance, but your sick leave still ends **28 Sept** unless renewed.

### **2. If redundancy *never* comes**
Eventually you’ll face the decision point yourself. The possibilities:  

- **Keep extending sick leave**: if your GP agrees, you could in theory stay off sick (paid) for months, though long-term sick can get complicated (occupational health referrals, HR reviews, etc.).  
- **Resign while on sick leave**: you don’t need to return first. You hand in notice, and as long as your GP continues to cover you, your notice period runs *while you’re signed off*. You wouldn’t work it in practice.  
- **If you resign when your sick note ends and don’t renew**: then you’re technically fit for work again and expected to return for your notice period.

- It buys you **time and income** now.  
- You don’t lose redundancy chance immediately (maybe it comes, maybe it doesn’t).  
- You don’t have to decide about resigning tomorrow or even after holiday — only once you hit your private deadline.  

### **4. The “worst-case” in Option B**
- You’re never made redundant.  
- You reach your private decision deadline (say late Sept).  
- You resign while still on a valid fit note.  
- GP extends your note for your notice period → you never actually go back in.

What are the positives if I'm made redundant?

Great question — redundancy can feel scary, but there are some real positives if it happens, especially compared with resigning yourself.  

---

## **Positives of being made redundant**  

### **1. Financial payout**  
- You’re legally entitled to **statutory redundancy pay** if you’ve been at AKQA for 2+ years (and many agencies also offer *enhanced redundancy packages*).  
- This could mean weeks or months of extra salary you wouldn’t get if you resign.  

---

### **2. No “burned bridge” narrative**  
- Redundancy is framed as **the company’s decision**, not yours — which protects your reputation.  
- In future interviews, you can say:  
  > “I was unfortunately made redundant during a restructure at AKQA.”  
- That lands far better than “I resigned because I was burnt out.”  

---

### **3. Access to benefits**  
- You remain eligible for **universal credit/job seeker support** immediately if you’re made redundant.  
- If you resign voluntarily, there can be a waiting period before state benefits kick in.  

---

### **4. Notice period paid**  
- You’ll still get paid your notice period (and often released early, with payment in lieu).  
- If you’re on sick leave at the time, the company usually still has to honour your redundancy pay and any unused annual leave payout.  

---

### **5. Emotional closure**  
- Redundancy can feel less personal: you were part of a restructure, not a single person walking away.  
- This can help with self-esteem and reduce the “I quit because I couldn’t cope” narrative.  

---

## **The only real downside**  
- You can’t control *if* or *when* it happens. You might wait and never get it.  
- And you can’t fully shape the timing — it’s on their schedule, not yours.  

---

👉 So redundancy is generally **more financially and reputationally advantageous** than resignation, as long as you’re comfortable staying in sick leave limbo while waiting.  

---

I can outline how this typically works in the UK and how you might approach a conversation, while keeping things professional and low-stress.

---

### 1. Pay and Statutory Sick Pay (SSP)

- **Company sick pay**: When your contractual company sick pay ends, you automatically move to **Statutory Sick Pay (SSP)** if you’re still employed and sending valid fit notes.  
- **You don’t need to “apply”** in a separate process. HR/payroll should automatically pay SSP as long as you remain employed and keep providing fit notes.  
- You simply need to keep submitting new fit notes to cover your absence.

---

### 2. Redundancy: what’s realistic

- **You can’t request redundancy** as if it were a benefit. Redundancy happens only if AKQA decides your role is no longer required (e.g., restructure, downsizing).
- However, you **can start a conversation** about the future of your role and, if appropriate, discuss a **mutual agreement/settlement**—sometimes called a “settlement agreement” or “mutually agreed exit.”
- Companies sometimes agree to a settlement when it’s clear an employee is not returning and both sides want to end the contract amicably.

---

### 3. How to frame the conversation

- **Ask for a meeting with HR/People Ops** (Alex or Maryam when she’s back).
- **Keep it neutral and forward-looking**. Don’t demand redundancy—focus on clarity and mutual agreement.

Example opening:
> “I’d like to have a confidential conversation about my longer-term employment status.  
> My health situation means I don’t expect to be able to return, and I’d like to discuss possible options for an agreed exit that works for both AKQA and me.”

- From there, HR might suggest:
  - Continuing on SSP until you’re ready to resign, or  
  - Exploring a settlement agreement (which can include a financial package and a reference).

---

### 4. Preparation tips

- **Review your contract**: note your notice period, any clauses about company sick pay, and redundancy/settlement language.
- **Keep fit notes up to date** so your SSP continues while discussions happen.
- **Stay factual and calm**: you’re not negotiating a windfall, you’re exploring a mutually beneficial exit.

---

### Key takeaway
You don’t need to “apply” for SSP—just keep sending fit notes.  
If you want a redundancy-style package, the practical route is to request a confidential meeting to discuss a *mutually agreed exit* or settlement, not to “ask for redundancy” outright.  

Would you like a concise email draft to HR requesting that private conversation?

Here’s a clear picture of your situation and choices:

---

### 1. Statutory Sick Pay (SSP)  
- **Rate (2025)**: **£116.75 per week** (before tax/NI).  
- **Duration**: Up to **28 weeks** as long as you remain employed and keep providing valid fit notes.  
- **Payment**: Your employer pays it automatically through payroll—you do **not** need to apply, just keep HR supplied with continuous fit notes.

---

### 2. Possible exit paths

**A. Remain on SSP and stay employed**  
- Keep submitting fit notes until either you recover, resign, or AKQA decides otherwise.  
- Pros: guaranteed SSP income; redundancy remains possible.  
- Cons: low pay, ongoing limbo.

**B. Voluntary resignation while on sick leave**  
- You can resign at any time, even while signed off.  
- Notice period runs during sick leave; you may not have to work if still covered by fit notes.  
- Pros: control over timing, closure.  
- Cons: no redundancy pay, SSP ends when employment ends.

**C. Negotiate a mutual agreement (settlement)**  
- Ask HR for a confidential conversation about “mutually agreed exit” or a “settlement agreement.”  
- Company might offer a lump-sum payment and a positive reference to avoid drawn-out sick leave.  
- Often used when return is unlikely and both sides want certainty.  
- Pros: can secure a payment larger than notice alone, plus a clean reference.  
- Cons: depends on AKQA’s willingness; you’ll likely sign a waiver of claims.

**D. Redundancy (if AKQA initiates)**
- Only if AKQA decides your role is no longer required.  
- You’d receive statutory (or possibly enhanced) redundancy pay **if you’ve been there 2+ years**:  
  - Half a week’s pay per year under age 22  
  - One week’s pay per year age 22–40  
  - 1.5 weeks per year age 41+  
  - Weekly pay capped at £700 (2025 rate) and total capped at 20 years’ service.
- Pros: lump-sum payout + paid notice + unused holiday.  
- Cons: you can’t trigger it yourself.

---

### 3. Recommended next steps
1. **Keep fit notes continuous** so SSP continues.  
2. **Review your contract** for notice period and any enhanced sick or redundancy terms.  
3. **Request a private meeting** with HR (e.g., Alex) to discuss a “mutually agreed exit” if you want to explore a settlement package.  
   - Sample opener:  
     > “Given my ongoing health issues and no foreseeable return date, I’d like to discuss possible options for an agreed exit that works for both AKQA and me.”  

---

This keeps you financially covered while opening the door to a negotiated settlement if redundancy isn’t offered.

It’s understandable to feel anxious—this is a big step and it’s hard to plan when you’re also recovering.  
Here’s a way to move forward while keeping control, avoiding unnecessary stress, and protecting your interests.

---

## 1.  You don’t have to take a call right away
You’re on holiday and still signed off sick.  
It’s completely reasonable to reply with something like:

> “Hi Alex, thanks for being flexible.  
> I’m currently away and focusing on my health.

## 2.  Keep the conversation future-focused
When you do speak (or email) you **don’t need to relive the project issues** unless you want to.

> “My doctor advises I won’t be able to return to work.

---

## 3.  What “a package” could look like
AKQA isn’t obliged to pay redundancy if your role still exists, but companies often offer a **settlement agreement** when:
- An employee is unlikely to return, and
- Both sides want a clean, amicable exit.

A settlement typically includes:
- A lump-sum payment (often more than notice pay).
- Payment for untaken holiday.
- A positive reference.
- Mutual confidentiality.

It’s perfectly reasonable to say you’d like to explore a “mutually agreed exit” or “settlement agreement.”  
You don’t need to name an amount; HR will outline what they can offer.

## 4.  Practical next step while you’re away

  * You’d appreciate a positive reference.

You can manage almost everything remotely if you’d rather not take a live call.  
Here’s a practical roadmap for handling a **mutually agreed exit / settlement** while you’re still away.

---

### 1.  Keep your sick leave active
* Continue sending fit notes on time so **Statutory Sick Pay (SSP)** continues.  
* No need for a call—emailing or uploading the fit note is enough.

---

### 2.  Open the exit conversation (written is fine)
You can start the process over Slack or email instead of a call:

> **Hi Alex,**  
> I’d like to discuss bringing my employment to a close in a way that works for both AKQA and me.  
> I’m currently away, so a written conversation would be easiest for me at the moment.  
> Could we begin to explore options—such as a mutually agreed exit—by email?  

This sets the tone without a live meeting and signals you’d like to handle it in writing.

---

### 3.  HR’s likely response
They may:
* Offer to continue by email, **or**
* Suggest a short call to outline next steps.

If they strongly prefer a call, you can still control the format:
* Request a short, scheduled video or phone call at a time that suits you.  
* Let them know you may keep your camera off and that you’ll follow up in writing.

---

### 4.  Key points to cover (in writing or on the call)
- **Your decision**: you won’t be able to return to work.  
- **Request**: explore a *mutually agreed exit/settlement agreement*.  
- **Practicalities**: ask what package or terms they can offer (lump-sum, holiday pay, reference).  
- **Next step**: request any proposal in writing for you to review.

You do **not** need to describe the project mismanagement or the full history—“ongoing health issues and advice from my doctor” is enough.

---

### 5.  After their proposal
- They will send a draft *settlement agreement* if they’re open to it.  
- You’ll need to take it to an **independent solicitor** (UK law requires legal advice for these agreements).  
- AKQA usually covers the solicitor’s fee for that review.

All of this can be handled entirely by email and couriered documents—you do not need to be in London.

---

### Quick checklist for a remote exit
- [ ] Keep fit notes continuous.  
- [ ] Send the written request to discuss a mutually agreed exit.  
- [ ] If a call is required, keep it short and ask for all terms in writing.  
- [ ] When/if you receive a draft settlement, forward to a solicitor (they’ll guide you on signing remotely).

---

So yes—you can start and largely complete this process from Crete.  
The only unavoidable “live” element might be a brief confirmation call, and even that can usually be handled by phone or Teams with your camera off.

* **Keeps you in control** – you set the agenda for a written discussion rather than a surprise phone call.

---

### ⚠️ **Potential cons / considerations**
* **Triggers formal dialogue** – once they know you won’t return, HR will begin next steps (which might include a settlement proposal or simply asking for a formal resignation).  
* **Removes ambiguity about redundancy** – if AKQA were quietly planning redundancies, they may now view you as voluntarily leaving, which could lessen any chance of a future redundancy payout.  
* **Starts a timeline** – depending on company policy, they may move to agree terms or suggest a mutually agreed termination date sooner than you expect.

---

### If you send it today
- You still keep **Statutory Sick Pay** while the discussion unfolds, as long as you provide fit notes until an agreement is signed.  
- You can take time to review any proposal; you are never obliged to sign quickly.  
- You can request that all communication remain in writing while you’re away.

---

### If you prefer to wait
- You preserve the small possibility of a redundancy package if AKQA independently decides to restructure your role.
- But you remain in limbo and may feel ongoing anxiety.

---

**Bottom line:**  
If your priority is clarity and moving on, sending it today is smart.  
If you want to hold out for any chance of a company-initiated redundancy, waiting a few more weeks carries that (small) advantage but keeps the uncertainty.

It’s understandable to wonder about this before you send anything.  
A few key points about redundancy at an agency like AKQA:

---

### 1. Redundancy depends on business need, not individual request  
- Redundancy is a legal process triggered when a role (or group of roles) is no longer required.  
- If the creative team is busy and billable, the company has **no obligation** to make a creative role redundant, even if other departments (like People Ops) have had cuts.

---

### 2. Your signals so far  
- You’re on extended sick leave and have said you don’t expect to return.  
- From the company’s perspective that’s a personal health situation, **not** a restructure reason.  
- HR may prefer a **mutual settlement** (a negotiated exit payment) rather than formal redundancy.

---

### 3. What’s more realistic  
- **Settlement agreement / mutually agreed exit**:  
  - Often offered when someone is long-term sick and unlikely to return.  
  - Usually includes: notice pay, untaken holiday pay, and sometimes an ex-gratia payment.  
  - You’ll need to sign a confidentiality/release of claims.  
- **Statutory redundancy**:  
  - Only if AKQA decides to reduce creative headcount in a formal restructure.  
  - No sign of that in your team right now.

---

### 4. Practical takeaway  
It’s **unlikely** you’ll be made redundant just because you’re off sick or want to leave.  
Your best route to a payout larger than simple notice is to **negotiate a settlement**—and HR is used to that language.  
That’s why framing it as a “mutually agreed exit” is wise.

---

So, if your goal is a package, focus your conversation with Alex on a **settlement agreement** rather than hoping for a creative-team redundancy that probably isn’t coming.

---

### 1. Your current leverage

- **Employer’s reality:**  
  AKQA must keep you on payroll (at least at the SSP rate) and manage your long-term absence. Over time that creates admin and uncertainty for them, which often leads companies to propose a *settlement agreement* for a clean break.

---

### 2. Why mentioning “exit” isn’t a problem  
- Your message simply opened a conversation; it doesn’t remove their incentive to settle.  
- HR will almost always try “support and return” first—it’s the standard playbook.

---

### 3. Recommended “waiting-game” approach
1. **Stay on sick leave.**  
   - Keep GP appointments and request each fit note to *follow on without gaps*.
   - You can remain on SSP for up to 28 weeks from the first day of absence.

2. **Keep communication minimal and factual.**  
   - Send each new fit note promptly.

3. **Do *not* resign.**

Since we'll likely have a call talking about what Alex mentioned about trying to get me back, what are some bullet points to go through in that to set me up for most likely getting a settlement as the end goal even if it won't be sorted until later.

Here’s a focused outline you can use for that call so you stay calm, protect your position, and quietly steer things toward a later settlement while never saying anything that weakens your leverage.

---

## Mind-set
- **Goal:** show that a return is not realistic while staying cooperative.  
- **Tone:** calm, appreciative, factual.  
- **Approach:** emphasise medical advice and uncertainty, not dissatisfaction with projects.

---

## Key Bullet Points to Cover

1. **Health & Medical Advice**  
   - “My GP continues to advise that I’m not fit to work and that recovery is unpredictable.”  
   - “I don’t have a timeframe for a safe return.”

2. **Commitment to Honest Communication**  
   - “I want to keep you updated so you can plan, and I’ll continue to provide fit notes promptly.”

3. **Impracticality of Adjustments**  
   - “Given the nature of my role—deadlines, client pressure, cross-team work—reasonable adjustments wouldn’t address the root issue.”  
   - “Even reduced hours or phased return wouldn’t be sustainable for me right now.”

4. **Desire for Clarity (without demanding exit)**  
   - “I understand this ongoing absence creates uncertainty for AKQA as well as for me.”  
   - “I’d like us to stay in touch about long-term options when it becomes clear I can’t return.”

5. **Leave the Door Open for a Mutual Agreement**  
   - “If, in future, the company feels a different arrangement or mutually agreed solution would make sense, I’m open to discussing that.”

---

## What **Not** to Do
- Don’t detail project mismanagement or blame colleagues—keep it about health and medical guidance.
- Don’t ask for a “payout” or name a figure.
- Don’t resign or give an end date.

---

## Follow-up
After the call, send a short email/Slack recap:
> “Thanks for the conversation today. As discussed, I’ll continue providing fit notes and will keep you informed as advised by my GP.”

---

### Why this sets you up well
- Confirms you are unfit for work and that adjustments won’t solve it.
- Shows you’re cooperative and transparent.
- Lets HR see that an indefinite sick leave is likely—making a **settlement agreement** the sensible future step, without you ever having to request it outright.

Here’s the situation as it stands and the practical next moves:

---

### Where things stand
* **Employment status:** You remain an AKQA employee, signed off as not fit for work until the date on your current fit note.

---

1. **Keep medical certification continuous**  
   * Book your next GP appointment early enough so the next note starts the day after the current one ends.  
   * Send each new note promptly to HR/Payroll.

2. **Minimal updates**  
   * If Alex checks in, a simple “I’m following medical advice and will provide the next fit note” is enough.  
   * No need to revisit projects or give a return date.

3. **Stay alert for HR outreach**  
   * If AKQA decides a mutually agreed exit makes sense, they’ll raise it.  
   * If/when they do, you can then discuss a settlement and request any offer in writing.

4. **Keep your own timeline**  
   * SSP can run for up to **28 weeks** from the start of your sickness period.  
   * You can decide later whether to continue on SSP, negotiate a settlement, or resign once you have a package or your own next step lined up.

### Key point
Right now, **the ball is in AKQA’s court**.  
Your only active task is to keep your fit notes coming and maintain polite, factual communication.  
Doing so maintains your income and keeps every option—especially a future settlement—open.

It sounds like Alex is following a very standard HR process:  
they have to **offer support and a “return-to-work” conversation first**, even when it’s clear you may not return.  
It doesn’t mean you must accept a call or commit to coming back.

Here’s how you can handle it without hurting your long-term goal of a settlement:

---

### 1. You’re not obliged to have a detailed call  
* A “conversation” in HR language can be **email, Slack, phone, or video**.  
* If you’re unwell or simply prefer written communication, you can say so.

Example:
> “Thanks for offering support.  
> I’m still following my GP’s advice and not able to engage in a return-to-work planning discussion right now.  
> I’d prefer to keep communication in writing and will update you when my medical situation changes.”

That satisfies their need for contact and keeps the ball with them.

---

### 2. Why you don’t want to dive into causes  
* Going into project details or grievances doesn’t strengthen a settlement case and can create side issues.  
* A short explanation—“work-related stress/burnout”—is enough.

---

### 3. Maintain your position  
* Continue providing fit notes on time.  
* Stay polite and responsive, but keep repeating that you’re **not fit to discuss a return** and that adjustments would not make a return possible *at this time*.

---

### 4. Why this helps you  
* It keeps SSP flowing.  
* It shows you’re cooperative but medically unfit, which is exactly the scenario that often leads a company to offer a **mutually agreed exit** later.

---

It sounds exhausting to feel trapped between “not working” and “not free.”  
Here are some practical and emotional angles you might find grounding:

---

### 1. Sick leave doesn’t mean you can’t *do anything*  
Being signed off means you’re **not fit to do your regular job**, not that you must sit completely idle.  
- You can work on **personal projects** (like a portfolio) or do light creative work if it supports recovery.  
- You just can’t start paid employment or freelance for income without telling HMRC/your employer.

So if building a portfolio feels therapeutic and manageable, it **doesn’t break your fit note**.

---

### 2. Your doctor decides, not the company  
- A GP can keep issuing fit notes as long as clinical reasons remain.  
- Stress and burnout can legitimately require many months of leave.  
- If you still have symptoms or the thought of AKQA work causes significant anxiety, your GP can continue certifying you.

---

### 3. How long AKQA might wait  
- Employers often *do* wait when someone is on long-term sick leave.  
- They rarely rush to offer a settlement unless it’s clear a return is impossible and continuing SSP is burdensome.  
- You can stay on SSP for **up to 28 weeks from the first sick day**—that’s the outer limit before any state benefits questions arise.

---

### 4. Your choices from here  
**A. Continue the steady path**  
   *Keep fit notes coming, focus on recovery/portfolio, accept that HR may move slowly.*  
   – Advantage: maintains income and keeps the door open for a settlement.  
   – Drawback: the limbo feeling.

**B. Nudge—gently**  
   *Once you’re ready, send a short written update:*  
   > “I remain unfit for work and do not anticipate a return.  
   > If AKQA wishes to discuss a mutually agreed exit at any stage, I’m open to that conversation.”  
   This isn’t pushing; it simply reaffirms what you’ve said.

**C. End it yourself (resign)**  
   *Gives certainty and frees you sooner but ends SSP and any chance of a package.*

---

### 5. Reframing the “limbo”
You are **not doing nothing**:
- You are in a legitimate recovery period.
- You can use this time for low-pressure portfolio work, therapy, rest, or planning next steps.

---

### Practical next step you might consider
- **Book your next GP review early** so there’s no gap in certification.  
- Give yourself a small, self-directed goal unrelated to AKQA (e.g., one portfolio piece, a daily walk, or a personal photo project) to regain a sense of forward motion.

---

You don’t need to force AKQA’s hand right now.  
Your legal and financial footing is secure as long as you maintain fit notes.  
You can use this space to recover and quietly prepare your portfolio so that when you *do* leave—on your terms—you’re ready for what’s next.

Here’s a calm, strategic way to handle this so you finish cleanly, protect yourself during notice, and keep the door open for buying the laptop later.

---

## 1.  Order of steps (best sequence)

**Step 1 – See your GP first**  
- Ask for another fit note that **extends past your intended resignation date and covers your full notice period**.  
- Say something like:

**Step 2 – Once you have (or know you’ll have) the fit note, then resign.**  
- That way, you can attach or refer to it in your resignation message and avoid being asked to return to work.

**Step 3 – Laptop discussion later.**  
- Wait until HR has acknowledged your resignation.  
- Once your final pay, holiday, and equipment return are being processed, politely ask about purchasing the device (“I’d be interested in buying the laptop if that’s possible once off-boarding is complete”).  
- It’s cleaner to separate that from your resignation.

## 2.  Practical checklist before sending the resignation
✅  Confirm your **notice period** in your contract (you mentioned eight weeks).  
✅  **Check holiday balance** – you’ll likely be paid for unused days.  
✅  Save any personal files or credentials you need (but not company IP).  
✅  Confirm your **final fit-note coverage** overlaps your notice period.  
✅  Keep a copy of everything you send and receive.

>   
> Best regards,  
> Felix  

---

## 4.  After you send it
- HR will confirm receipt and outline your final date, pay, and equipment process.  
- Keep sending fit notes if the GP issues them in shorter increments.  
- You don’t need to mention the laptop until the off-boarding logistics email arrives.

---

2. **Then send** the short, polite resignation.  
3. **Laptop conversation later.**

This sequence keeps everything professional, protects you medically and financially, and ensures a smooth exit.

## **What Reclassifying Those Holiday Days Actually Does**

When those holiday days are converted back into *sick leave*, a few things happen automatically:

### **1. Your annual leave balance increases**
Those days are credited back to your holiday pot.

So instead of having **3.5 days left**, you’ll likely have **around 8.5–9.5 days** left total (depending on whether both blocks are counted fully — we’ll confirm once they reply).

### **2. You then choose what happens to those extra days:**
You can either:
- **Have them paid out** in your final salary (you receive more cash)
**or**
- **Use them to shorten your notice period** (meaning your contractual end date moves *earlier*)

You do **not** need to choose now.  
You can decide *after* they confirm the corrected balance.

That’s why we **do not** mention any intentions yet — we want the balance corrected *first*, without signalling how you plan to use it.

---

## **So what could it “naturally” end up as?**
Whichever gives *you* the most benefit:

| Option | Outcome | When it's good |
|-------|---------|----------------|
| **Use the extra holiday days to shorten the notice** | Your employment ends sooner | If you want to be free faster |
| **Get the extra days paid out** | You receive more money in your final paycheck | If you want maximum cash benefit |

**You are free to choose later.** Do **not** commit now.

So yes — the reclassification **can**:
- Shorten your notice *and/or*
- Increase your final pay

The smart move is:  
**Confirm the corrected holiday number first.**  
Then we choose the best option for you.

---

## **About the Laptop Purchase**

Do **not** mention the laptop in the same message.

Reason:
You are currently in the **clean admin phase** (resignation confirmation + leave balance correction).  
The laptop request should be sent **later**, once offboarding steps begin — usually after HR sends the formal offboarding email.

If you ask now, it risks:
- Distracting from the holiday correction (which is worth more £££)

If I want the best free diving sites in crete, Greece. Where should I stay+

For the best freediving in Crete, you’ll want to base yourself somewhere with easy access to deep, clear water, low boat traffic, and ideally a local freediving school or club. Here are the top spots and where to stay:

---

### 🟦 **Agia Pelagia (North Coast, near Heraklion)**
- **Why stay here:** Crystal-clear waters, calm coves, dramatic underwater landscapes (caves, cliffs), and easy access to Heraklion Airport.
- **Freediving benefit:** Great visibility and access from shore or boat to beautiful depths.
- **Accommodation:** Boutique hotels, affordable apartments. Quiet, relaxing vibe.
- **Nearby schools:** Freediving Club Greece operates from Heraklion.

---

### 🟦 **Chania Region (West Crete) – Stay in **Kissamos** or **Chania Town**
- **Why stay here:** Access to the stunning Balos Lagoon, Elafonissi, and the Gramvousa area. Deep drop-offs not far from shore.
- **Freediving benefit:** Beautiful reef walls and caves, fewer tourists than the east.
- **Accommodation:** Kissamos is quieter; Chania is vibrant with great food and culture.
- **Nearby schools:** *Blue Adventures Diving* in Chania sometimes offers freediving courses.

---

### 🟦 **Plakias (South Coast)**
- **Why stay here:** Remote, relaxed, with access to deep water right off the beach. Less wind and more consistent conditions in summer.
- **Freediving benefit:** Great for depth training and exploration. Close to beaches like Skinaria and Damnoni.
- **Accommodation:** Chill backpacker spots, beach studios, and a few midrange hotels.
- **Nearby schools:** *Dive2Gether* in Plakias offers freediving options.

---

### 🟦 **Myrtos or Ierapetra (South-East Coast)**
- **Why stay here:** Some of the deepest, clearest water on the island, minimal tourist traffic, peaceful local vibe.
- **Freediving benefit:** Superb for training, very calm sea, deep quickly.
- **Accommodation:** Simple, local-run places. Quiet and ideal if you’re self-directed or experienced.

---

### Recommendations by Style:
| If you want… | Stay in… |
|--------------|----------|
| Depth training & calm water | **Plakias** or **Myrtos** |
| Vibrant culture & convenience | **Chania** or **Heraklion/Agia Pelagia** |
| Seclusion & pure nature | **South coast (Myrtos, Lentas)** |
| Easy beginner dives + beauty | **Agia Pelagia** |

---

Here’s a detailed look at **Gavdos** — what it is, what you’ll find, what to expect — especially useful if you might head there as a freediver or nature‑lover.

---

## 📍 Key Facts

| Feature | Detail |
|---|---|
| Location | South of Crete, in the Libyan Sea. Administrative region: Chania. It’s the southernmost inhabited island of Greece (and often described as the southernmost point of Europe). citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search7 |
| Size | ~ **32 km²** including nearby islets like Gavdopoula. citeturn0search0turn0search4turn0search1 |
| Population | Very small permanent population (≈ 140 as of 2021). In summer, tourists (especially campers) swell the numbers. citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search5 |
| Highest point | Mount Vardia, about **345 m** elevation. citeturn0search0turn0search16 |
| Climate | Very warm summers, mild winters. Lots of sun. Dry in summer, wetter in winter. citeturn0search0 |

---

## 🌿 What Makes Gavdos Special

- **Wild, raw and remote** — very little development. Many beaches are undeveloped or minimally developed. Great for those after nature, simplicity, and isolation. citeturn0search2turn0search1  
- **Outstanding beaches & coastline** — crystal‑clear waters, sandy / pebbly bays, cliffs, sea caves. Examples include *Potamos*, *Sarakiniko*, *Agios Ioannis*, *Diana Beach*, *Tripiti* etc. citeturn0image0turn0search1turn0search2turn0search6  
- **Birdlife & nature** — It and nearby islets (like Gavdopoula) are important for migratory birds. Vegetation: phrygana, juniper / pine patches. citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search11  
- **Ideal for slow travel** — many people stay camping, hiking, enjoying quiet, disconnected pace. citeturn0search2turn0search6  

---

## 🛠 Practical Info & Things to Know

| Topic | Details |
|---|---------|
| Access / Transport | Ferries connect from ports on southern Crete (e.g. Chora Sfakion, Paleochora, Sougia) to the port of Karave on Gavdos. Schedules can be limited, especially outside peak summer. citeturn0search8turn0search1 |

Can you be naked at omprogialos beach, or beaches in general if you sit a bit to the side away from people? What's the general Consensus in Crete?

Yes — **you can often be naked on beaches in Crete**, including *many* that are not officially designated nudist beaches, **as long as you're respectful, discreet, and away from families or crowds**. The general consensus across Crete — especially in less touristy or remote areas — is **relaxed and tolerant**, though not everywhere is equally accepting.

---

## 🌿 **Omprogialos Beach (also spelled Ombrosgialos)**

- It’s a **small rocky cove** east of Chania, **20–30 min west of Almyrida**, with **clear waters and few people**.  
- There’s **no sand**, just a concrete platform and rocks for diving and sunbathing.
- It’s **not an official nudist beach**, and there’s **a taverna right by the water**, so nudity **directly at the main platform isn’t advised**.
- However, if you **walk/swim a bit away from the main platform**, especially in the early morning or late afternoon when fewer people are around, **topless or nude sunbathing/swimming is often tolerated**.

---

## 🏝️ **Crete Nudity Consensus: What's Generally Accepted**

| Area | Nudity Tolerance | Notes |
|------|------------------|-------|
| **Remote / hard-to-reach beaches** | 🟢 *Very tolerant* | Nudism common. As long as you give space and are respectful, no issue. |
| **Touristy but large beaches** | 🟡 *Mixed* | Go to one end, away from families. Nudity might be fine, especially if others are doing it. |
| **Small beaches with tavernas or hotels** | 🔴 *Less tolerant* | Stay clothed around main areas. Nudity may offend locals or other visitors. |
| **Popular naturist beaches (e.g., Filaki, Glyka Nera, Gavdos)** | ✅ *Widely accepted* | Nudity is the norm or explicitly allowed. No issues here. |

---

## ✅ Tips for Going Nude in Crete

- **Distance = acceptance**: Walk/swim away from others. 100m makes a big difference.
- **No frontal nudity near tavernas, paths, or boats**.
- **Early morning / late afternoon** is your friend for solitude.
- **If in doubt**: observe others. If no one else is nude and it’s busy, best to wait or move on.

---

Hur mycket liter per nm använder en ny 4taks 6hk motor utombordare

En modern fyrtakts **6 hk utombordare** drar förvånansvärt lite bränsle vid marschfart. Ungefärliga siffror:  

- **Bränsleförbrukning på fullgas**: ca **2,5 liter per timme**.  
- Vid normal marschfart (halv–två tredjedels gas): ca **1,2–1,8 liter per timme**.  

Om vi räknar i **liter per nautisk mil (nm)** beror det på farten:  

- I en båt som Maxi 77 gör en 6 hk motor ungefär **4–5 knop** i marschfart.  
- Det ger ett snitt på ca **0,3–0,4 liter per nautisk mil**.  

Alltså: du kan räkna med runt **1,5 liter i timmen** → vid 4–5 knop ≈ **0,35 l/nm**.  

Vill du att jag gör en tabell med olika farter vs. förbrukning så du kan planera räckvidd och tankstorlek?

Du sa att motorn gjorde ungefär 4-5 knop i marschfart. Vad skulle max hastighet vara? Är marschfart liksom utmaxad? Jag skulle säga att jag vill köra typ två tredjedels fart ungefär av att man är i maxfarten på den här motorn. För min Maxi 77 får du tänka på att den sitter fart på också. Och då vet du ju vikten och sånt där.

Kort och tydligt:

- **Teoretisk maxfart (skrovfart) för Maxi 77** ≈ **6,0 kn**  
  (LWL ~ 6,0 m → skrovfart ≈ 1,34 × √(19,7 fot) ≈ 6 kn).  
- **Praktisk max under motor (6 hk, slät sjö, ren botten)**: **5,0–5,5 kn**. En 6-hästars orkar sällan pressa en Maxi 77 hela vägen till 6 kn annat än i perfekt läge.
- **Marschfart** är *inte* utmaxad. På en deplacementbåt ger 2/3 gas ofta ~80–90 % av toppfarten (effektbehovet stiger ungefär med farten³).  
  → **Rimlig marschfart 2/3 gas**: **4,2–4,8 kn**.

### Rekommendation för din planering
- Räkna med **4,5 kn** som realistisk marschfart på 2/3 gas.  
- Bränsle vid den farten: ungefär **1,4–1,7 l/h** ⇒ **0,30–0,38 l/nm**.  
- Vid fullgas **5,0–5,5 kn**: cirka **2,3–2,7 l/h** ⇒ **~0,42–0,49 l/nm**.

### Så får du ut mest av 6 hk på en Maxi 77
- **“Sail/High-Thrust”-propeller** (större diameter, lägre stigning) ger bättre tryck vid låg fart.  
- **Rätt montagehöjd**: kavitationstallriken i nivå med båtens botten.  
- **Ren botten och rätt lasttrim** gör stor skillnad.  
- **Snäll sjö**: motvind/vågor sänker farten markant för samma gaspådrag.

Hur lång tid skulle det ungefär ta att segla från Hastings till Le Portel Outreau i vindar runt 4-6m/s

Kort och rakt:

### Snabb uppskattning
- **Distans rak linje** Hastings → Le Portel/Outreau: ~**39 nm**.  
- **Maxi 77 i 4–6 m/s (8–12 kn vind)** gör oftast **4–5,5 kn** över vatten beroende på bog och sjö.

| Antagande | Effektiv distans | Medelfart (VMG) | Tidsåtgång |
|---|---:|---:|---:|
| Beam/broad reach, lite kryss | **43 nm** (≈ +10%) | **4,5–5,5 kn** | **7,8–9,6 h** |
| Blandade bogar, neutral tidvatten | **43 nm** | **4–5 kn** | **8,6–10,8 h** |
| Mycket kryss + motström | **49 nm** (≈ +25%) | **3,5–4,5 kn** | **10,9–14,0 h** |

**Praktiskt intervall:** räkna med **~9–12 timmar**. Med rätt bogar och medström kan det bli **8–9 h**; hård kryss eller motström gör det snarare **12–14 h**.

### Noter som gör störst skillnad
- **Tidvatten i Engelska kanalen**: ±1–2 kn i SOG. Starta så att du får **medström** över den mesta sträckan.  
- **Bog/VMG**: Kryss ökar både distans (tackvinklar) och minskar fart → stor tidsförlust.  
- **Ren botten/lasttrim/propeller** (om du kör motorstöd i bleke) påverkar 0,3–0,5 kn lätt.

What is contentful and why is it considered "headless"? What does that mean?

**Contentful** is a **headless content management system (CMS)**. Let's break that down:

---

### 🧠 What is Contentful?
Contentful is a platform where you can:
- **Create and manage content** (text, images, video, etc.)
- **Structure it using content models** (like blog posts, products, team bios)
- **Deliver it through APIs** to any device or interface (websites, apps, kiosks, etc.)

It's used by developers and content teams who want more flexibility than traditional website builders like WordPress.

---

### 🏗️ What does “Headless” mean?
In a **traditional CMS** like WordPress:
- The “head” (front-end: how the content looks) and the “body” (back-end: where content is stored) are tightly connected.
- The CMS controls both content and presentation.

In a **headless CMS** like Contentful:
- The “head” is removed—**it doesn’t care how or where your content is displayed**.
- You manage your content in Contentful, but build your front-end however you like (React, Next.js, mobile app, etc.).
- Content is delivered via **APIs (usually REST or GraphQL)**.

---

### 🧩 Why is this useful?
- **Omnichannel delivery**: One content source, many destinations (website, mobile, smartwatch, etc.)
- **Developer freedom**: Use any tech stack for the front-end.
- **Scalability**: Easier to scale across multiple platforms or brands.

---

### Example
Imagine you're launching a product:
- In Contentful, your team enters the product name, description, price, and images.
- Your website, mobile app, and in-store display can **pull that content from Contentful** and render it in their own unique ways—without duplication.

---

### 🪓 Why is it called “headless”?

### 🧠 What is Contentful — and what does “headless” mean?
**Contentful is a headless CMS**, meaning it:
- **Stores content** (like product info, page copy, images) in a structured, central place.
- **Delivers it via APIs** to any front-end (website, app, even screens in stores).
- Does **not include a front-end (“head”)** — that’s built separately using whatever technology your team prefers (e.g. React, Next.js, etc.).

---

### 🧩 Why does this matter for John Frieda?
You’re doing things like:
- Creating **page templates**, **component toolkits**, and **content migration plans**
- Working across **UK and Germany**, likely with localisation needs
- Defining **filters, UGC, wishlist** features — all of which need scalable content models

**Contentful supports this by:**
- Letting you model content types (e.g. Product, Filter Option, Article) with fields like text, images, tags, etc.
- Making components reusable across markets while keeping content dynamic and localisable
- Giving editors (like the John Frieda team) a friendly UI to manage content — no code required
- Integrating with tools like **Gatsby**, **Next.js**, or **Vercel** to serve fast, SEO-friendly pages

---

| Dev-ready design package           | Clean separation of content & layout = easier implementation            |
| Content guidelines                 | Content types enforce structure and tone consistency                   |

- Personalised features (e.g. filters, quizzes, UGC)

### 🚀 This isn’t just a redesign. It’s a relaunch.  
A relaunch of **brand voice**, **editorial quality**, and **technical capability**.

To create a **copy of your existing Figma file** (including the variables) and use it for the **John Frieda** project, follow these steps:

---

### ✅ If You Want a New File With All the Variables and Components:

1. **Open your Triumph Figma file**.

   - All styles
   - All components

After copying:
1. Go through each page and **delete Triumph-specific frames or UI**.
2. Keep:
   - The **Design System pages**
   - **Variables** (found under **Local Variables** in the right panel)
   - Any **component libraries** or tokens you want to reuse

---

### 🔗 If You're Using Variables From a Library:
If your variables were **published to a library**, you can:
- Just **link to that library** in the John Frieda file via **Assets > Team Library > Enable** the Triumph file.
- Or, duplicate the variables into the new file if you want them **locally scoped** to John Frieda.

---

### 🛠 Want to Rename Variables for John Frieda?
Go to:
- **Local Variables** → Right-click → **Rename Collection**
- Or create a **new collection** and move variables over.

How do you move single files into a team and project?

To move a **single Figma file** into a **team and project**, follow these steps:

---

### ✅ **If you're using the Figma desktop app or web:**

1. **Go to your "Drafts" or wherever the file is currently located.**
2. **Right-click** on the file you want to move.
3. Select **“Move to Project…”**
4. In the popup:
   - First, **select the team** you want to move it into (e.g., *John Frieda*).
   - Then choose the specific **project** within that team (or create a new one).
5. Click **“Move”**.

---

### 📝 Notes:
- If you're **not a member of the destination team**, you won’t see the option.
- You can only move files to **teams you have at least Editor access** in.
- Files moved from Drafts become visible to team/project members, depending on sharing settings.

How do I get my duplicate variable local copy into this team and project?

To bring your **duplicate variables** into the **John Frieda team/project** and make them local and editable, here’s exactly what to do:

---

### ✅ Option 1: **Publish Variables from Your Copied File to the Team Library**

1. **Open your copied Triumph file** (now renamed for John Frieda).
2. In the right panel, go to **Local Variables**.
3. Click **“Publish”** in the top right of the Variables panel.
4. Figma will ask if you want to publish variables (and optionally styles/components).
5. Hit **Publish** — this now makes your variables available as a **team library** for use in other John Frieda project files.

✔️ *Now those variables are accessible across the whole team, and you’re in control of future edits.*

---

### ✅ Option 2: **Move the File into the John Frieda Project (if not already)**

If your file still lives in “Drafts” or outside the team:

1. Go to the file browser view.
2. **Right-click** the file → **Move to Project…**
3. Choose your **John Frieda team** and the right **project folder**.
4. Once moved, your file and its variables are now part of the **team environment**.

---

### 🛠 Bonus Tip: If You Want the Variables Inside Another File (e.g. new layout file)

- In your new file (within the John Frieda team), go to **Assets > Team Library**.
- **Enable the library** where you published the variables (from the previous steps).
- Now those variables are available to apply in this new file too.

You're likely running into this issue because **Figma doesn’t support uploading custom fonts to team libraries directly via the browser or desktop app UI** unless you’re on **Figma Enterprise** or using **Figma Organization** with **Shared Fonts** enabled.

Here’s what’s happening and what you can do:

---

### 🔒 Why it’s not working
- The **“Shared Fonts”** tab you’re in is only available for **Enterprise/Org-level teams** that support shared font hosting.
- Figma **won’t allow uploading `.ttf` or `.otf` fonts here** unless you have **admin rights** on an Org account with the shared font feature activated.

---

### ✅ Workarounds

#### 1. **Local Font Install (Desktop-only workaround)**
If you're on a **Pro** or **Free** plan:
- Install **Futura.ttf** on your **computer** (double-click > Install).
- Then use the **Figma desktop app** — it will automatically detect and use your local system fonts.

> ⚠️ This only works *for you*. Others on your team won’t see the font unless they’ve installed it too.

---

#### 2. **Enterprise route (Team-wide use)**
If you're on **Figma Enterprise**:
- Admins can go to **Admin settings > Shared Fonts** and upload fonts there.
- Then they become usable by the whole team in any file.

---

#### 3. **Fallback Option**
If you want something available to everyone:
- Use a **Google Font** or a Figma-native font with a similar feel to Futura (like *Inter*, *Outfit*, or *Suisse Int’l* if licensed).

---

Let me know your account level (Pro, Org, or Enterprise), and I can guide you through the exact steps or find a matching Google Font if you'd like a substitute.

Is there a minimum height for buttons for ios

Yes, Apple provides clear guidance on **minimum button sizes** for iOS to ensure usability, particularly for touch targets:

---

### 📱 **Apple’s Minimum Tap Target (Button) Size:**

- **Minimum height (recommended):** **44pt** (points)
- **Minimum width (recommended):** **44pt**
- **Guideline source:** Apple’s [Human Interface Guidelines (HIG)](https://developer.apple.com/design/human-interface-guidelines/foundations/layout/#touch-targets)

---

### 🔍 Why this matters:
- This size ensures that buttons are easily tappable by users of all ages and dexterities.
- It applies **even if the visual element (icon, text)** is smaller — the *interactive area* must still be 44×44pt at minimum.
- This is especially important for **navigation**, **forms**, **CTAs**, and **icon buttons**.

---

### ✅ Best practice:
Even if your visual design calls for smaller buttons (e.g., minimalist UI), **pad the tappable area invisibly** using layout spacing or hit-slop in code.

Let me know if you need Android equivalents or examples of this applied in Figma specs.
What are recommended height for standard ?

For **iOS standard button heights**, Apple doesn't enforce fixed heights beyond the minimum tap target (44pt), but there are **common conventions and best practices** used across native apps and design systems like Apple’s own UI components:

---

### 📏 **Recommended Standard Button Heights (iOS)**

#### 🧩 **Primary & Secondary Buttons**
- **Standard height:** **48pt–52pt**
- **Minimum height:** **44pt** (for compact UIs or space-limited layouts)
- **Max comfortable height:** **60pt** (only for prominent CTA buttons)

> ✳️ 48pt is often considered the sweet spot — balancing visual elegance and touch comfort.

---

#### 🔲 **Icon-Only Buttons**
- **Size (tap target):** Still **44×44pt minimum**, even if the icon itself is smaller
- Visual size can be 24pt–32pt, but the hit area must be padded to 44pt+

---

#### 🧾 **Text-Only Buttons (e.g. “Cancel”, “Edit”)**
- Height depends on text size + padding, but should **still meet the 44pt tap target**
- Typical height: **40–44pt**

---

### ✍️ Summary Table:

| Button Type           | Visual Height | Tappable Height |
|-----------------------|---------------|-----------------|
| Primary / CTA         | 48–52pt       | ≥44pt           |
| Icon-Only             | 24–32pt icon  | ≥44pt           |
| Text-Only             | ~40–44pt      | ≥44pt           |

---
